thread.title: 'Why should I end up with a smaller pension than a male colleague?'
thread.title_full: 'Why should I end up with a smaller pension than a male colleague?'

author: James Connington
title: 'Why should I end up with a smaller pension than a male colleague?'

organizations.name: rose st louis of zurich insurance

text:
W omen receive substantially less in employer pension contributions than men, setting them up for a far poorer retirement, new research has found.
It suggests the smaller contributions by firms mean female employees will end up with a pension pot worth an average £47,000 less than their male counterparts.
Between 2013 and 2016, men benefited from employer pension contributions worth 7.8pc of their salary each year, compared with 7pc for women.
That difference amounts to an average potential deficit of £47,000 by the end of a 42 year working life. 
The analysis, from insurer Zurich, is based on 250,000 pension plans.
It is a not a historic phenomenon applying only to older generations of workers.
Last year, men under the age of 35 received £217 more on average in employer pension contributions than women of the same age.
The explanations go beyond the gender wage gap, which currently stands at 9.4pc, according to the Office for National Statistics' latest survey of earnings . 
Sign up to our emails M en are more likely to work in sectors with generous pension schemes, and are more likely to be promoted into senior roles, which often come with better pension deals. 
A report from the Chartered Management Institute last year found that in management roles men were promoted 40pc more often than women . 
Additionally, out of the 250,000 plans analysed by Zurich, 155,000 were held by men, indicating that “there are significantly more men receiving pension contributions in the first place” according to the report. 
Watch | Tips for managing your pension before retirement 02:25 A spokesperson for the Department for Work and Pensions said that the number of women employed in the private sector with a workplace pension has doubled since 2012 but "there is still more to do". 
Rose St Louis of Zurich Insurance said: “The impact of the gender pay gap on womens' pensions is no secret, but the difference in the contributions they receive from employers is a serious problem.
“The triple effect of smaller salaries, career breaks for women and lower contribution rates needs to be addressed.”
Zoe Gibbs, 28, a finance assistant from London, is enrolled in her company pension but like most in their twenties is unsure of the level it will reach by the time she retires.
She is concerned however about where the responsibility for counteracting any inequality will fall.
Zoe Gibbs, 28 Credit: John Nguyen/JNVisuals S he said: “If a woman has a career break, or isn’t given the opportunity to reach top positions, then she can never hope to have the same amount at retirement.
“I don’t believe I should put more of my money in now to make up for the inequality over my working life. There are other things you need to be saving for when you’re 28.”
